clusters.title: European leaders to join Zelenskyy at White House meeting on Monday, says Ursula von der Leyen – live
clusters.neutral_headline: European Leaders to Meet Zelenskyy in Washington
bullet_summary: The European Commission on Sunday said that President Ursula Von der Leyen and other European leaders will accompany Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky for talks with US President Donald Trump
If the meeting goes well, Trump said he would then push for a three-way meeting between Russia, Ukraine and the US to try to seal a "peace agreement"
No deal has been reached to end the war in Ukraine - but Donald Trump has said there are "many points" he and Vladimir Putin agreed on during their highly anticipated summit

items.title: European leaders to join Zelenskyy at White House meeting on Monday, says Ursula von der Leyen – live
items.standfirst: European Commission president says she and other European leaders will meet Donald Trump on Monday after Ukrainian president’s requestGermany’s chancellor, Friedrich Merz, will also be travelling to Washington tomorrow for the Trump-Zelenskyy talks, according to the federal government.The chancellor’s spokesperson has been quoted by BBC News as having said:The trip will serve as an exchange of information with US President Donald Trump following his meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Alaska.Chancellor Merz will discuss the status of peace efforts with the heads of state and government and underscore Germany’s interest in a swift peace agreement in Ukraine. Continue reading...
items.content: European Commission president says she and other European leaders will meet Donald Trump on Monday after Ukrainian president’s requestGermany’s chancellor, Friedrich Merz, will also be travelling to Washington tomorrow for the Trump-Zelenskyy talks, according to the federal government.The chancellor’s spokesperson has been quoted by BBC News as having said:The trip will serve as an exchange of information with US President Donald Trump following his meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Alaska.Chancellor Merz will discuss the status of peace efforts with the heads of state and government and underscore Germany’s interest in a swift peace agreement in Ukraine. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump drops ceasefire demand, echoing Putin’s position and jittering Ukraine
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump reversed course after his meeting in Alaska with Russia’s Vladimir Putin by abandoning his demand for a ceasefire and adopting a Kremlin position calling for a full peace deal to end the Ukraine war.
items.content: US President Donald Trump reversed course after his meeting in Alaska with Russia’s Vladimir Putin by abandoning his demand for a ceasefire and adopting a Kremlin position calling for a full peace deal to end the Ukraine war.

items.title: European leaders to join Zelenskyy in Washington after Trump's shift toward Putin

items.content: Ukraine and its allies were scrambling Sunday to respond to President Donald Trump's apparent shift toward Vladimir Putin's hardline position after their summit in Alaska.

items.content: The US president will meet his Ukrainian counterpart in Washington on Monday in the wake of his Alaska summit with Vladimir Putin on Friday.

items.title: EU chief von der Leyen to join Zelensky for talks in Washington Monday
items.standfirst: The European Commission on Sunday said that President Ursula Von der Leyen and other European leaders will accompany Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky for talks with US President Donald Trump. Set to take place Monday in Washington, the meeting follows the collapse of a proposed ceasefire at the Trump-Putin summit in Alaska. Follow our liveblog for the latest developments.
items.content: The European Commission on Sunday said that President Ursula Von der Leyen and other European leaders will accompany Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky for talks with US President Donald Trump. Set to take place Monday in Washington, the meeting follows the collapse of a proposed ceasefire at the Trump-Putin summit in Alaska. Follow our liveblog for the latest developments.

items.content: Trump, Putin meeting in Alaska ends without a ceasefire deal; Meet chef Ana Sortun.

items.title: No concessions, no ceasefire: how Putin outplayed Trump in Anchorage
items.standfirst: Russia’s leader seems to have drawn the US president closer to Moscow’s position on the Ukraine war
items.content: Russia’s leader seems to have drawn the US president closer to Moscow’s position on the Ukraine war

items.title: ‘Fear’ in Ukraine following Trump-Putin talks
items.standfirst: Ukrainians have expressed fears that Kyiv’s position is no longer being heard in Washington, says FRANCE 24’s Emmanuelle Chaze, reporting from Kyiv. Following the meeting between President Donald Trump and President Vladimir Putin in Alaska, Ukrainians have noted the failure of the US and Russian leaders to agree on the need for a ceasefire.
items.content: Ukrainians have expressed fears that Kyiv’s position is no longer being heard in Washington, says FRANCE 24’s Emmanuelle Chaze, reporting from Kyiv. Following the meeting between President Donald Trump and President Vladimir Putin in Alaska, Ukrainians have noted the failure of the US and Russian leaders to agree on the need for a ceasefire.

items.title: Starmer to meet European leaders for 'coalition of the willing' talks on Ukraine
items.standfirst: European leaders who make up the 'coalition of the willing' are set to hold a conference call on Sunday - ahead of crunch talks between Donald Trump and Ukraine's Volodymyr Zelenskyy next week.
items.content: European leaders who make up the 'coalition of the willing' are set to hold a conference call on Sunday - ahead of crunch talks between Donald Trump and Ukraine's Volodymyr Zelenskyy next week.

items.title: Zelenskyy may be asked to cede land to Russia at Trump meeting in Washington
items.standfirst: Ukrainian leader to return to White House after Alaska summit between US president and Vladimir PutinUkraine’s president has said he will fly to Washington on Monday to meet Donald Trump after the Alaska summit amid speculation that the US president will ask him to cede territory to end the war.Next week’s meeting will mark the first return to the White House for Volodymyr Zelenskyy since his infamous row with Trump and the vice-president, JD Vance, in the Oval Office in February. Continue reading...
items.content: Ukrainian leader to return to White House after Alaska summit between US president and Vladimir PutinUkraine’s president has said he will fly to Washington on Monday to meet Donald Trump after the Alaska summit amid speculation that the US president will ask him to cede territory to end the war.Next week’s meeting will mark the first return to the White House for Volodymyr Zelenskyy since his infamous row with Trump and the vice-president, JD Vance, in the Oval Office in February. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump to meet Ukraine’s Zelenskyy after ‘successful’ talks with Putin
items.standfirst: US president changes position on Ukraine, saying he prefers direct peace accord instead of ceasefire after Alaska talks.
items.content: US president changes position on Ukraine, saying he prefers direct peace accord instead of ceasefire after Alaska talks.

items.title: Ukraine's Zelensky to meet Trump on Monday after Alaska summit fails to secure ceasefire
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said he will meet US President Donald Trump at the White House in Washington on Monday after a Russia-US summit ended without an agreement to stop the fighting in Ukraine. If the meeting goes well, Trump said he would then push for a three-way meeting between Russia, Ukraine and the US to try to seal a "peace agreement".
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said he will meet US President Donald Trump at the White House in Washington on Monday after a Russia-US summit ended without an agreement to stop the fighting in Ukraine. If the meeting goes well, Trump said he would then push for a three-way meeting between Russia, Ukraine and the US to try to seal a "peace agreement".

items.title: War rages on in Ukraine as Trump and Putin meet but don’t announce deal
items.standfirst: NBC News’ Richard Engel reports from the frontlines in Ukraine as the summit between President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin ends without a ceasefire.
items.content: NBC News’ Richard Engel reports from the frontlines in Ukraine as the summit between President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin ends without a ceasefire.

items.title: How the Trump-Putin summit unfolded... in under 2 minutes
items.standfirst: The meeting concluded with no deal being reached between Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin but "great progress" was made in Ukraine talks.
items.content: The meeting concluded with no deal being reached between Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin but "great progress" was made in Ukraine talks.

items.title: Trump says Xi told him China will not invade Taiwan while he is in office
items.standfirst: US president says Chinese counterpart told him ‘I am very patient and China is very patient’The US president, Donald Trump, has said that his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, told him China would not invade Taiwan while Trump is in office.Trump made the comments in an interview with Fox News on Friday, ahead of talks with the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, over Moscow’s invasion of Ukraine. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: No deal has been reached to end the war in Ukraine - but Donald Trump has said there are "many points" he and Vladimir Putin agreed on during their highly anticipated summit.

clusters.ai_summary:
• European leaders will join Zelenskyy in Washington for talks with Donald Trump.
• Germany's chancellor will discuss peace efforts with heads of state and government.
• The meeting follows Trump's summit with Vladimir Putin in Alaska.
• Trump has shifted toward Putin's position on a full peace deal.
• Zelenskyy is seeking to counter Trump's shift with European support.

clusters.title: Air Canada to resume flights after directive ending strike
clusters.neutral_headline: Air Canada to Resume Flights After Strike Ends
bullet_summary: Air Canada said it would resume flights Sunday after a government directive to end a flight attendants' strike
Federal Jobs Minister Patty Hajdu said now is not the time to take…

items.title: Air Canada to resume flights after directive ending strike
items.standfirst: Air Canada said it would resume flights Sunday after a government directive to end a flight attendants' strike. The Canadian Industrial Relations Board (CIRB) "has directed Air Canada to resume airline operations and for all Air Canada and Air Canada Rouge flight attendants to resume their duties"…
items.content: Air Canada said it would resume flights Sunday after a government directive to end a flight attendants' strike. The Canadian Industrial Relations Board (CIRB) "has directed Air Canada to resume airline operations and for all Air Canada and Air Canada Rouge flight attendants to resume their duties"…

items.title: Air Canada to resume flights after directive ending strike
items.standfirst: Air Canada said it would resume flights Sunday after a government directive to end a flight attendants' strike
items.content: Air Canada said it would resume flights Sunday after a government directive to end a flight attendants' strike

items.title: Air Canada to resume flights after government ends flight attendant strike
items.standfirst: Canada’s labour board has ordered Air Canada to resume operations after a nationwide flight attendant strike grounded over 700 flights. The directive, issued following a request from Jobs Minister Patty Hajdu, marks the end of the airline’s first flight attendant walkout since 1985.
items.content: Canada’s labour board has ordered Air Canada to resume operations after a nationwide flight attendant strike grounded over 700 flights. The directive, issued following a request from Jobs Minister Patty Hajdu, marks the end of the airline’s first flight attendant walkout since 1985.

items.title: Air Canada to Resume Flights Sunday After Government Ends Strike
Government forces Air Canada and flight attendants back to work and into arbitration, after strike strands over 100,000 travelers
items.standfirst: Canada’s government forced Air Canada and its striking flight attendants back to work and into arbitration Saturday after a work stoppage stranded more than 100,000 travelers around the world during the peak summer travel season. Federal Jobs Minister Patty Hajdu said now is not the time to take…
items.content: Canada’s government forced Air Canada and its striking flight attendants back to work and into arbitration Saturday after a work stoppage stranded more than 100,000 travelers around the world during the peak summer travel season. Federal Jobs Minister Patty Hajdu said now is not the time to take…

items.title: Canada moves to end Air Canada strike, seeks binding arbitration
items.standfirst: The Canadian government on Saturday moved to end a strike by Air Canada's cabin crews and require binding arbitration to break their contract impasse, an action that the country's largest carrier had sought but unionized flight attendants fiercely opposed. Thousands of Air Canada flight attendants…
items.content: The Canadian government on Saturday moved to end a strike by Air Canada's cabin crews and require binding arbitration to break their contract impasse, an action that the country's largest carrier had sought but unionized flight attendants fiercely opposed. Thousands of Air Canada flight attendants…

items.title: Government forces Air Canada and flight attendants back to work and into arbitration
items.standfirst: By Rob Gillies and Wyatte Grantham-Philips | Associated Press TORONTO — Canada’s government forced Air Canada and its striking flight attendants back to work and into arbitration Saturday after a work stoppage stranded more than 100,000 travelers around the world during the peak summer travel…
items.content: By Rob Gillies and Wyatte Grantham-Philips | Associated Press TORONTO — Canada’s government forced Air Canada and its striking flight attendants back to work and into arbitration Saturday after a work stoppage stranded more than 100,000 travelers around the world during the peak summer travel…

items.title: Air Canada flight attendants' strike grounds hundreds of planes
items.standfirst: The Canadian government is moving quickly to shut down a strike that has grounded the country's biggest airline. Air Canada flight attendants walked off at the job early Saturday, stranding thousands of passengers across North America and beyond. CBS News New York's Ali Bauman reports on the fallout.
items.content: The Canadian government is moving quickly to shut down a strike that has grounded the country's biggest airline. Air Canada flight attendants walked off at the job early Saturday, stranding thousands of passengers across North America and beyond. CBS News New York's Ali Bauman reports on the fallout.

items.title: What to know as Air Canada grounds flights and attendants strike
items.standfirst: Air Canada advises passengers not to go to the airport unless they have tickets on other airlines.
items.content: Air Canada advises passengers not to go to the airport unless they have tickets on other airlines.

items.title: Canadian government orders arbitration to resolve Air Canada flight attendants' strike
items.standfirst: Air Canada suspended all operations Saturday morning after more than 10,000 flight attendants walked off the job over pay and scheduling disputes, prompting the Canadian government to step in.
items.content: Air Canada suspended all operations Saturday morning after more than 10,000 flight attendants walked off the job over pay and scheduling disputes, prompting the Canadian government to step in.

items.title: Canadian government intervenes to end Air Canada flight attendant strike
items.standfirst: The Canadian government on Saturday intervened to end a strike by Air Canada flight attendants by asking a labour board to order an arbitration. The strike stranded more than 100,000 passengers across the world during the peak summer holiday season.
items.content: The Canadian government on Saturday intervened to end a strike by Air Canada flight attendants by asking a labour board to order an arbitration. The strike stranded more than 100,000 passengers across the world during the peak summer holiday season.

items.title: Government forces Air Canada flight attendants back to work, into arbitration
items.standfirst: Canada's government forced Air Canada and its striking flight attendants back to work and into arbitration Saturday after a work stoppage stranded more than 100,000 travelers around the world.
items.content: Canada's government forced Air Canada and its striking flight attendants back to work and into arbitration Saturday after a work stoppage stranded more than 100,000 travelers around the world.(Image credit: Sammy Kogan)

clusters.ai_summary:
• Air Canada will resume flights after a government directive.
• The Canadian Industrial Relations Board ordered the airline to resume operations.
• The directive ended a flight attendants' strike.
• The strike stranded over 100,000 travelers.
• The government is seeking binding arbitration to resolve the contract impasse.

clusters.title: More than 200 missing in flood-hit district in Pakistan, official says
clusters.neutral_headline: Pakistan Floods Cause Hundreds of Deaths and Missing
bullet_summary: Hundreds are reported missing in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province as a result of devastating floods
At least 150 people are missing in northwest Pakistan, the head of the provincial disaster authority said Sunday (August 17), after flash floods that have killed at least 344 people in the country
At least 150 people are missing in Pakistan’s Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province following devastating flash floods that have killed at least 344 nationwide, officials said Sunday

items.title: More than 200 missing in flood-hit district in Pakistan, official says
items.standfirst: Hundreds are reported missing in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province as a result of devastating floods.
items.content: Hundreds are reported missing in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province as a result of devastating floods.

items.title: Pakistan expands rescue and relief efforts after flash floods
items.standfirst: At least 150 people are missing in northwest Pakistan, the head of the provincial disaster authority said Sunday (August 17), after flash floods that have killed at least 344 people in the country. Thousands of rescuers were battling rain and knee-deep mud, digging homes out from under massive boulders in a desperate search for survivors.
items.content: At least 150 people are missing in northwest Pakistan, the head of the provincial disaster authority said Sunday (August 17), after flash floods that have killed at least 344 people in the country. Thousands of rescuers were battling rain and knee-deep mud, digging homes out from under massive boulders in a desperate search for survivors.

items.title: At least 150 still missing in Pakistan after deadly flash floods
items.standfirst: At least 150 people are missing in Pakistan’s Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province following devastating flash floods that have killed at least 344 nationwide, officials said Sunday. Rescue efforts are underway, with fears that many victims may be trapped under rubble or swept away by raging waters.
items.content: At least 150 people are missing in Pakistan’s Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province following devastating flash floods that have killed at least 344 nationwide, officials said Sunday. Rescue efforts are underway, with fears that many victims may be trapped under rubble or swept away by raging waters.

items.title: Death toll after monsoon floods in Pakistan rises to more than 320
items.standfirst: Most of the dead were reported in the mountainous province of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, with more rain forecastThe death toll from heavy monsoon rains that have triggered flash floods across northern Pakistan has risen to at least 321 people in the past 48 hours, the country’s disaster authority said on Saturday.The majority of the deaths, 307, were recorded in the mountainous Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, according to the National Disaster Management Authority. Continue reading...
items.content: Most of the dead were reported in the mountainous province of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, with more rain forecastThe death toll from heavy monsoon rains that have triggered flash floods across northern Pakistan has risen to at least 321 people in the past 48 hours, the country’s disaster authority said on Saturday.The majority of the deaths, 307, were recorded in the mountainous Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, according to the National Disaster Management Authority. Continue reading...

items.title: Flash floods kill at least 159 people in Pakistan after huge cloudburst
items.standfirst: Search for the missing continues in north-west after downpour also sparks deadly flooding and landslides in IndiaA massive cloudburst has triggered flash floods in north-west Pakistan, killing at least 157 people, as rescuers continued to search for people missing after floods in neighbouring India.Mohammad Suhail, a provincial emergency services spokesperson, said 78 bodies were recovered from various parts of Buner district in the north-west province of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa by noon on Friday, and a further 79 were pulled later from the rubble of collapsed homes and flooded villages. Continue reading...
items.content: Search for the missing continues in north-west after downpour also sparks deadly flooding and landslides in IndiaA massive cloudburst has triggered flash floods in north-west Pakistan, killing at least 157 people, as rescuers continued to search for people missing after floods in neighbouring India.Mohammad Suhail, a provincial emergency services spokesperson, said 78 bodies were recovered from various parts of Buner district in the north-west province of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa by noon on Friday, and a further 79 were pulled later from the rubble of collapsed homes and flooded villages. Continue reading...

clusters.ai_summary:
• Flash floods in Pakistan have killed over 344 people.
• Over 150 people remain missing in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province.
• Rescue efforts are underway in the flood-hit areas.
• The majority of deaths occurred in the mountainous Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province.
• Heavy monsoon rains triggered the devastating floods.

clusters.title: Israeli military prepares to move Palestinians to southern Gaza
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel Prepares to Move Palestinians in Gaza
bullet_summary: Israel on Saturday said it is preparing to move Palestinians from combat zones to southern Gaza as plans move ahead for a military offensive in some of the territory's most populated areas
Reported by France24, CBS News, Al Jazeera

items.title: Israeli military prepares to move Palestinians to southern Gaza
items.standfirst: International condemnation and pressure from allies have done nothing to stop Israel's plan to displace the people of northern Gaza. Israel on Saturday (August 16) said it is preparing to move Palestinians from combat zones to southern Gaza as plans move ahead for a military offensive in some of the territory's most populated areas
items.content: International condemnation and pressure from allies have done nothing to stop Israel's plan to displace the people of northern Gaza. Israel on Saturday (August 16) said it is preparing to move Palestinians from combat zones to southern Gaza as plans move ahead for a military offensive in some of the territory's most populated areas

items.title: Nationwide protests over Gaza war, hostage deal sweep Israel
items.standfirst: Demonstrators rallied across Israel on Sunday (August 17), demanding an end to the war in Gaza and a deal to free the remaining hostages, as the military readies a new offensive. The protests come amid rising domestic pressure and international concern over the humanitarian crisis in the Palestinian territory. Protest organisers and the main campaign group representing the families of hostages also called for a general strike.
items.content: Demonstrators rallied across Israel on Sunday (August 17), demanding an end to the war in Gaza and a deal to free the remaining hostages, as the military readies a new offensive. The protests come amid rising domestic pressure and international concern over the humanitarian crisis in the Palestinian territory. Protest organisers and the main campaign group representing the families of hostages also called for a general strike.

items.title: Nationwide protests over Gaza war, hostage deal sweep Israel
items.standfirst: Demonstrators rallied across Israel on Sunday, demanding an end to the war in Gaza and a deal to free the remaining hostages as the military readies a new offensive. The protests come amid rising domestic pressure and international concern over the humanitarian crisis in the Palestinian territory.
items.content: Demonstrators rallied across Israel on Sunday, demanding an end to the war in Gaza and a deal to free the remaining hostages as the military readies a new offensive. The protests come amid rising domestic pressure and international concern over the humanitarian crisis in the Palestinian territory.

items.title: Israel prepares to move Palestinians to southern Gaza amid protest over war
items.standfirst: The Israeli military body in charge of humanitarian aid to Gaza said the supply of tents and other shelter equipment to the territory would resume on Sunday ahead of the mass movement of Palestinians to the south.
items.content: The Israeli military body in charge of humanitarian aid to Gaza said the supply of tents and other shelter equipment to the territory would resume on Sunday ahead of the mass movement of Palestinians to the south.

items.title: Israeli army prepares to relocate Palestinians to southern Gaza
items.standfirst: Israel on Saturday said it is preparing to move Palestinians from combat zones to southern Gaza as plans move ahead for a military offensive in some of the territory's most populated areas. Meanwhile the families of Israeli hostages called for a “nationwide day of stoppage” on Sunday to express growing frustration over 22 months of war.
items.content: Israel on Saturday said it is preparing to move Palestinians from combat zones to southern Gaza as plans move ahead for a military offensive in some of the territory's most populated areas. Meanwhile the families of Israeli hostages called for a “nationwide day of stoppage” on Sunday to express growing frustration over 22 months of war.

items.title: Israel preparing to forcibly displace Palestinians to southern Gaza
items.standfirst: Plans move ahead for a military offensive in some of the territory's most populated areas, amid move to seize Gaza City.
items.content: Plans move ahead for a military offensive in some of the territory's most populated areas, amid move to seize Gaza City.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Israel is preparing to move Palestinians to southern Gaza.
• The move is part of plans for a military offensive.
• Protests are occurring across Israel over the war.
• Families of hostages are calling for a day of stoppage.
• The Israeli military will resume supplying tents to Gaza.

clusters.title: Three Republican-led states to send hundreds of National Guard troops to Washington
clusters.neutral_headline: States Deploy National Guard Troops to Washington
bullet_summary: West Virginia said it was deploying 300 to 400 guard troops, while South Carolina pledged 200 and Ohio said it would send 150 in the coming days
The protest comes as West Virginia, South Carolina, and Ohio announced they would deploy hundreds of additional National Guard troops to the nation's capital

items.title: Three Republican-led states to send hundreds of National Guard troops to Washington
items.standfirst: West Virginia said it was deploying 300 to 400 Guard troops, while South Carolina pledged 200 and Ohio says it will send 150 in the coming days, marking a significant escalation of the federal intervention.
items.content: West Virginia said it was deploying 300 to 400 Guard troops, while South Carolina pledged 200 and Ohio says it will send 150 in the coming days, marking a significant escalation of the federal intervention.(Image credit: Julia Demaree Nikhinson)

items.title: Three states to deploy hundreds of national guard troops to Washington DC
items.standfirst: South Carolina and Ohio join West Virginia in pledging troops, fueling protests that national guard should not be used for ‘a political policing mission’Three states have moved to deploy hundreds of members of their national guard to the nation’s capital as part of the Trump administration’s effort to overhaul policing in Washington through a federal crackdown. West Virginia said it was deploying 300 to 400 guard troops, while South Carolina pledged 200 and Ohio said it would send 150 in the coming days.The moves announced on Saturday came as protesters pushed back on federal law enforcement and national guard troops fanning out in the heavily Democratic city following Donald Trump’s executive order federalizing local police forces and activating about 800 District of Columbia national guard members. Continue reading...
items.content: South Carolina and Ohio join West Virginia in pledging troops, fueling protests that national guard should not be used for ‘a political policing mission’Three states have moved to deploy hundreds of members of their national guard to the nation’s capital as part of the Trump administration’s effort to overhaul policing in Washington through a federal crackdown. West Virginia said it was deploying 300 to 400 guard troops, while South Carolina pledged 200 and Ohio said it would send 150 in the coming days.The moves announced on Saturday came as protesters pushed back on federal law enforcement and national guard troops fanning out in the heavily Democratic city following Donald Trump’s executive order federalizing local police forces and activating about 800 District of Columbia national guard members. Continue reading...

items.title: D.C. Residents Protest Trump's Federal Police Takeover Plan
items.standfirst: The protest comes as West Virginia, South Carolina, and Ohio announced they would deploy hundreds of additional National Guard troops to the nation's capital.
items.content: The protest comes as West Virginia, South Carolina, and Ohio announced they would deploy hundreds of additional National Guard troops to the nation's capital.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Three states are deploying National Guard troops to Washington DC.
• West Virginia, South Carolina, and Ohio are sending troops.
• The deployments are part of a federal policing effort.
• Protests are occurring against the federal police takeover plan.
• The moves follow Donald Trump's executive order.

items.title: Video shows prominent Palestinian prisoner for the first time in years

items.content: The world got a glimpse of Marwan Barghouti for the first time in years in a video of a far-right Israeli minister berating him. (Image credit: Bernat Armangue)

items.title: Israeli minister posts video online confronting Palestinian detainee in his prison cell – as it happened
items.standfirst: Far-right national security minister Itamar Ben Gvir posts video showing him confronting Marwan Barghouti, who has spent more than 20 years in Israeli custodyAt least 16 Palestinian people, including five aid seekers, have been killed in Israeli attacks on Gaza since dawn, Al Jazeera is reporting, citing medical sources.Here are some of the latest images being sent to us over the newswires from Gaza: Continue reading...

clusters.title: Tensions soar in Serbia as protesters clash with police, set fire to party offices
clusters.neutral_headline: Protests and Clashes in Serbia Continue
bullet_summary: Reported by France24, NBC World

items.title: Tensions soar in Serbia as protesters clash with police, set fire to party offices
items.standfirst: Fresh clashes erupted late Saturday (august 17) between protesters and riot police in Serbia's capital Belgrade and other cities, on the fifth consecutive night of unrest. Almost daily protests have gripped Serbia since November, following the collapse of a railway station roof that killed 16 people. The tragedy became a symbol of deep-rooted corruption in the Balkan nation, with demands for a transparent investigation growing into calls for early elections.
items.content: Fresh clashes erupted late Saturday (august 17) between protesters and riot police in Serbia's capital Belgrade and other cities, on the fifth consecutive night of unrest. Almost daily protests have gripped Serbia since November, following the collapse of a railway station roof that killed 16 people. The tragedy became a symbol of deep-rooted corruption in the Balkan nation, with demands for a transparent investigation growing into calls for early elections.

items.title: Serbian police use tear gas against protesters in Belgrade
items.standfirst: Serbian police officers threw tear gas and charged against protesters as tensions escalated between authorities and anti-government protesters in the capital. The country has been gripped by protests since November, when a train station canopy collapse killed 16 people. Many blamed the tragedy on poor renovation work resulting from widespread corruption in infrastructure projects.
items.content: Serbian police officers threw tear gas and charged against protesters as tensions escalated between authorities and anti-government protesters in the capital. The country has been gripped by protests since November, when a train station canopy collapse killed 16 people. Many blamed the tragedy on poor renovation work resulting from widespread corruption in infrastructure projects.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Protests and clashes continue in Serbia.
• Protesters clashed with police in Belgrade.
• The protests have occurred for five consecutive nights.
• The protests began after a train station roof collapse.
• Protesters are demanding early elections.

items.standfirst: Bookshop chain says people are keen to escape their screens and says rise in sales is partly down to BookTok Times may be tough on the high street but the bookseller Waterstones is enjoying strong sales as younger adults embrace reading as an escape from their screens and as online competition…
items.content: Bookshop chain says people are keen to escape their screens and says rise in sales is partly down to BookTok Times may be tough on the high street but the bookseller Waterstones is enjoying strong sales as younger adults embrace reading as an escape from their screens and as online competition…

items.title: Waterstones opens 10 new stores a year as younger adults embrace reading
items.standfirst: Bookshop chain says people are keen to escape their screens and says rise in sales is partly down to BookTokTimes may be tough on the high street but the bookseller Waterstones is enjoying strong sales as younger adults embrace reading as an escape from their screens and as online competition eases.“People have come back to reading and buying books in bookshops as we have made a place which is an enjoyable and effective way to buy books,” says James Daunt, the CEO of the British retailer, which has 320 UK bookshops and owns the Foyles, Hatchards and Blackwell’s names, and whose parent group also owns Barnes & Noble, the US’s largest bookstore chain. Continue reading...
items.content: Bookshop chain says people are keen to escape their screens and says rise in sales is partly down to BookTokTimes may be tough on the high street but the bookseller Waterstones is enjoying strong sales as younger adults embrace reading as an escape from their screens and as online competition eases.“People have come back to reading and buying books in bookshops as we have made a place which is an enjoyable and effective way to buy books,” says James Daunt, the CEO of the British retailer, which has 320 UK bookshops and owns the Foyles, Hatchards and Blackwell’s names, and whose parent group also owns Barnes & Noble, the US’s largest bookstore chain. Continue reading...

clusters.ai_summary:
• Waterstones is opening new stores due to rising sales.
• Younger adults are embracing reading.
• Sales are partly due to BookTok.
• The retailer has 320 UK bookshops.
• People are seeking an escape from screens.

• The storm's intensity fluctuated significantly over a short period.
